audio_caption: The clip begins with a welcoming message from a male speaker with a friendly and informative tone, who introduces the topic of the Earth's location. He acknowledges the apparent simplicity of the question before clarifying that the focus is on Earth's location within the Milky Way galaxy. This speaking section is underscored by calm, gentle background music.

The clip begins with one male speaker discussing how astronomers believed that the Earth was once the center of the universe, due to the perspective from Earth, stating that "everything is orbiting around the planet Earth." He continues to say that only in the last couple centuries have observations shown that the Earth orbits the sun. He discusses how the sun orbits the Milky Way galaxy and that we have only known for a century that we are part of this larger picture. He ends the clip by stating that astronomers want to know where the Earth lies relative to the Milky Way galaxy. The overall tone is educational and calm.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing the Milky Way, emphasizing its immense size. He clarifies that it's "really, really big," citing measurements in light-years.  Soft, ambient music plays in the background throughout the speech, maintaining a calm tone.

The audio begins with a male speaker discussing the Milky Way's size and shape, noting it eats other galaxies and mentioning dwarf galaxies such as Canis Major and Sagittarius. The speaker maintains an informative tone, further emphasizing the Milky Way's size in relation to others such as the Andromeda galaxy.

The audio clip begins with a single male speaker, whose tone is inquisitive and educational. He discusses the structure of the Milky Way galaxy, describing its barred spiral nature and the formation of spiral arms. The speaker conveys that the arms are made up of dense "density waves" that orbit around, which compress gas and dust. The male speaker continues, emphasizing that these arms have been observed. He transitions, stating it's impossible to photograph the entirety of the Milky Way from outside, indicating that images are either artists' depictions or similar galaxies.

A male speaker describes the challenges scientists face in determining the appearance of the Milky Way galaxy, explaining, "it is very difficult" because "we're within it." He notes that it has only been through "decades of observation" and "comparisons to other galaxies" that a "clear picture" has emerged. The tone is informative.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing the estimation of stars, spiral arms, structural rigidity, and the structure of dark matter in the Milky Way galaxy based on current research, adopting an informative tone. He proceeds to explain that the arms of the Milky Way are composed of dust and gas, comprising 10 to 15% of all luminous matter. A musical tune with a gentle, ethereal character then starts, possibly created with synthesizers.

The audio begins with a male speaker discussing the size of the galaxy, noting that we can only see a portion of it in the visible spectrum, citing light pollution and a "dusty ring of the Milky Way" as an obstacle. He continues, in an informative and relatively calm tone, explaining how infrared astronomy helps overcome this by allowing us to see heat from stars and filter out gas and dust. The audio concludes with the speaker emphasizing that this enables a better understanding of the Milky Way's structure.

The audio clip features one male speaker discussing dark matter, explaining it surrounds the Milky Way and constitutes a large percentage of its mass, stating that "we know it's there, but we don't know what it's made of". He notes that its mass can be inferred from galactic rotation speed and that it keeps galaxies intact. The tone of the speaker is informative and educational.

The audio clip features a male speaker presenting information. He states "The solar system is located about 25,000 light years away from the galactic center" and continues to explain the solar system's position relative to the galaxy, maintaining a calm and informative tone.

The clip begins with a male speaker, speaking in an informative tone, explaining that "the milky way has two major spiral arms," and describing their names and locations. In the background, there is subtle music playing, evoking a sense of wonder. The speaker continues, describing the location of the solar system. Finally, the speaker explains that looking at the Milky Way in the night sky, it is rather equal from both hemispheres, meaning the solar system lies relatively close to the galactic plane.

The audio clip features a single male speaker narrating facts about the Milky Way. He mentions its "relatively low surface brightness" due to gases and dust, the Sun's long galactic year of "over 200 million years," and our solar system's continuous movement in a galactic orbit. The speaker's tone is informative and calm. A subtle background music is present, creating a spacey, contemplative mood with ethereal synths.

The audio begins with a male speaker reflecting on humanity's expanding understanding of the universe, mentioning advancements in knowledge about the galaxy's structure, composition, Earth's location, and the potential future of our galaxy and planet Earth; he delivers this information in an informative tone. The audio transitions to gentle piano music that conveys a pensive and serene mood.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker finishing a statement, inviting the listener to learn more about the Milky Way and encouraging them to like and subscribe. Gentle and dreamy music with a mournful quality starts playing, seemingly from strings, creating a reflective atmosphere. A new male speaker then begins discussing the star Betelgeuse. Describing it as a red giant star, he emphasizes its massive size.
